LOAN AND PROGRAM SUMMARY 

Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka

The  Financial  Markets  Program  for  Private  Sector  Development 
(the  Program)  (formerly  Private  Sector  Development  Program 
[PSDP]  subprogram  II)  is  the  second  subprogram  of  the  cluster 
loan  approved  by  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  in 
December 2000. The cluster program supports the creation of an 
enabling  environment 
for  private  sector  development.  The 
proposed  Program  and  actions  are  intended  to  complement  the 
results  achieved  by  the  PSDP  subprogram  I,  particularly  in  the 
areas  of  (i)  developing  financial  markets  and  the  private  sector's 
access  to  finance,  and  (ii)  supporting  the  Government's  public 
enterprise  reform  program  in  the  banking  industry  through  the 
newly created Strategic Enterprise Management Agency (SEMA). 
The Program will be implemented from 2005 to 2007. 
 
The  Program  consists  of  two  loans:  (i)  a  policy  (program)  loan, 
amounting  to  $60  million  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources 
(OCR); and (ii) a technical assistance (TA) loan, amounting to $5 
million equivalent, from ADB’s Special Funds resources. 
 
 
 
If Sri Lanka is to meet its long-term objectives of reducing chronic 
unemployment, raising standards of living, maintaining high levels 
of human development, and reducing poverty, the economy must 
grow  at  a  faster  rate  on  a  sustained  basis.  To  achieve  these 
objectives, the country needs to enhance productivity, reduce the 
financial  burden  of  state-owned  enterprises  (SOEs)  on  the 
economy,  and  mobilize  larger  amounts  of  investment  capital  to 
rebuild  the  country's  infrastructure  after  20  years  of  civil  war. 
Public  resources  can  only  finance  a  part  of  these  needs.  The 
Government recognizes that to meet its resource requirements, it 
needs  to  rely  on  the  private  sector,  while  developing  the 
appropriate market environment for faster economic growth.

The Program seeks to facilitate participation of the private sector 
including  small-  and  medium-sized  enterprises  (SMEs)  in  the  Sri 
Lankan  economy  by  supporting  government  reforms  to  eliminate 
impediments  to  and  develop  opportunities  for  their  involvement. 
Although the country is experiencing economic growth, most of it 
is  being  generated  from  larger  enterprises  and/or  SMEs  in 
industrial areas. The Program aims to create a private sector that 
would  take  a  lead  role  in  generating  employment,  boosting 
economic growth, and raising income levels for a larger segment 
of the population, including rural areas. 
 
In  this  context,  the  Program  will  support  the  development  of 
financial  markets,  a  key  constraint  for  economic  growth  for  the 
private  sector  and  SMEs.  People's  Bank  (PBank),  the  second 
largest  bank  in  the  country,  with  an  extensive  nationwide  branch 
network  particularly  in  rural  areas,  will  play  a  pivotal  role  in 
servicing the commercial, SMEs, and retail sectors. 
 
The principal objective of the Program is to facilitate private sector 
development by strengthening the financial markets, including the 
restructuring and phased recapitalization of PBank. The Program 
will have the following elements: (i) developing financial markets; 
and  (ii)  strengthening  the  banking  system.  This  includes  further 
restructuring  of  PBank,  based  on  an  agreed  time  schedule  to 
meet  certain  performance  targets  to  improve  efficiency  and 
profitability.  PBank  will  be  recapitalized  in  phases  in  accordance 
with  the  recapitalization  plan.  The  focus  areas  of  the  proposed 
Program build on the results of PSDP subprogram I. 
 
The adjustment costs associated with reforms under the Program 
are estimated to total $90 million.  
 
The  program  loan  will  support  focused  policy  reforms.  A  loan  in 
the amount of $60,000,000 will be provided to the Government of 
Sri Lanka (Government) as Borrower at standard OCR terms with 
a 15-year amortization period, including a grace period of 3 years; 
an  interest  rate  to  be  determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility, and 
a  commitment  charge  for  the  undisbursed  balance  of  0.75%  per 
annum and such other terms and conditions set forth in the loan 
agreement for the Program. (A front-end fee of 1% will be waived 
for loans approved before 30 June 2005).

program  implementation  and  steering  committee  chaired  by  the 
Secretary  of  the  Treasury  and  comprising  representatives  from

The loan is expected to be utilized within 36 months from the date 
of loan effectiveness. It will be released in three equal tranches of 
$20  million  each.  The  first  tranche  will  be  made  available  upon 
loan effectiveness. The second and third tranches will be released 
upon compliance with specified conditions in the policy matrix. 
 
The  counterpart  funds  to  be  generated  out  of  the  loan  proceeds 
will  be  used  to  meet  program  expenditures  and  related  costs  of 
reforms for financial markets and private sector development.  
 
The  technical  assistance  (TA)  loan  will:  (i)  provide  capacity 
building  and  skills  development  for  PBank;  (ii)  strengthen  the 
insurance industry through capacity building of IBSL; (iii) create a 
national  computerized  registry  system  for  securing  movable 
property;  (iv)  provide  banking  expertise  to  work  for  SEMA  to 
improve  its  ability  to  manage  four  banks  in  its  portfolio;  and  (v) 
provide  legal  and  governance  expertise  for  corporate  securities, 
financial  markets,  and  commercial  and  banking,  law  and  policy 
reforms.  
 
The total cost of the TA loan is estimated at $6 million equivalent. 
The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  will  finance  $5  million 
equivalent. The Government will contribute $1 million equivalent. 
 
ADB  will  provide  a  TA  loan  of  SDR3,318,000  from  its  Special 
Funds resources for a term of 32 years, including a grace period 
of  8  years,  an  interest  rate  of  1.0%  per  annum  during  the  grace 
period, and 1.5% per annum thereafter. The TA loan closing date 
is expected to be 31 December 2007. 
 
The  MOFP  will  be  the  Executing  Agency  of  the  TA.  IBSL,  the

The population as a whole will benefit from (i) the development of 
financial markets; and (ii) a stronger banking system through the 
restructuring and phased-in recapitalization of PBank. A dynamic 
private  sector  will  enable  creation  of  employment  and  thereby 
assist in reducing poverty. 
 
Political  Risk.  A  cease-fire  is  in  effect  after  a  20-year  civil  war. 
Although  the  Government  has  a  clear  intent  to  seek  a  peaceful 
resolution  to  the  conflict,  no  permanent  solution  has  yet  been 
reached.  Delays  in  the  peace  process  could  (i)  weaken  private 
sector  development;  (ii)  hinder  the  development  of  financial 
markets,  including  attracting  the  needed  investment  capital  to 
rebuild and/or modernize the infrastructure of the country; and (iii) 
undermine  the  will  to  introduce  and  implement  necessary  policy 
reforms.  There  is  strong  government  commitment  toward  policy 
reforms  although  the  progress  in  the  peace  process  is  largely 
beyond the control of the Program. 
 
Implementation Risk. Delays may occur in the implementation of 
reforms due to lack of capacity and/or skills. The Government has 
requested  capacity  building  through  the  TA  loan  as  an  integral 
part of the Program.  
 
The  loan  and  policy  reform  components  under  the  Program 
involve various bills and/or amendment to existing acts pertaining 
to  financial  and  commercial  reforms  to  be  approved  by  the 
Cabinet  and/or  introduced  into  Parliament.  This  includes  the 
SEMA  Act  which  is  a  key  component  of  the  Program.  However, 
there  are  political  risks  that  such  bills  and/or  amendment  to  acts 
may  not  be  enacted  by  Parliament  despite  the  Government’s 
strong commitment, and if enacted, may not be implemented. 
 
The risk in the restructuring and phased recapitalization of PBank 
is  the  board  of  directors’  and  management's  success  in  meeting 
or exceeding the performance targets. PBank must also generate

the  Government  on  one  side;  and  (ii)  the  board  of  directors  and

Moreover, the Government agrees to a phased-in recapitalization 
of  PBank  to  meet  minimum  core-capital  requirements  up  to  a 
maximum of SLRs8.5 billion subject to PBank meeting a timetable 
of pre-established financial performance targets.  
 
Restructuring of PBank has substantial labor and human relations 
issues. Labor unions in Sri Lanka are active and their acceptance 
of  the  restructuring  plan  will  be  key  to  effective  implementation 
under the Program. PBank is required to enter into an agreement 
with  the  union  representing  85%  of  the  employees  by  30 
September 2005. There is a risk that this may not occur. 
 
Macroeconomic  Risk.  Despite  generally  sound  economic 
developments,  the  fiscal  deficit  has  begun  to  widen  in  2004 
reflecting  inter  alia  some  weakening  in  revenue  performance,

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on proposed loans 
to the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka (Sri Lanka) for the Financial Markets Program 
for Private Sector Development (the Program). 
 

II. 

THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT  

The most important political challenge facing the Government of Sri Lanka (Government) 
2. 
is  finding  a  lasting  solution  to  the  civil  conflict.  Following  two  decades  of  civil  unrest,  a  formal 
agreement  to  cease  hostilities  and  restore  normalcy  to  the  country  was  signed  in  February 
2002. Since then, the continuation of the ceasefire and the advancement of measures toward a 
permanent solution for peace have served to support strengthened sociopolitical and economic 
stability. While the Government and the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Ealam continue to honor the 
ceasefire  agreement,  the  peace  process  remains  on  hold  until  an  agreed  framework  and 
approach for negotiations can be developed.1 
 
3. 
Despite the long period of civil unrest, Sri Lanka’s economy has proved to be resilient. 
Growth rates averaged 4.2% per year during the 1980s—supported by the commencement of 
the Government’s liberalization measures and significant large-scale public sector infrastructure 
investments,  and  5.2%  in  the  1990s—fueled  by  the  implementation  of  the  Government’s 
economic policy reform program focused on supporting private sector-led growth.  
 
4. 
The  economy  of  Sri  Lanka  has  performed  well  over  the  past  few  years  since  the 
ceasefire  agreement.  Gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  growth  was  5.9%  in  2003  and  based  on 
first half year GDP growth rate of 5.7%, latest estimates suggest GDP growth of around 5.2% in 
2004, notwithstanding the impact on the economy of the oil price shock and a severe drought. 
Economic  growth  has  been  broad  based  driven  primarily  by  growth  in  the  service  sector 
reflecting  the  impact  of  improved  security  conditions  on  business  activity.  Although  the  official 
unemployment rate declined from 9.1% in 2002 to 8.4% in 2003, unemployment continues to be 
a problem for the country. 
 
Stabilization of inflation has been a key component of the Government’s macroeconomic 
5. 
program.  The  Colombo  Consumer  Price  Index  (CCPI)  inflation  declined  to  6.3%  in  2003  from 
9.6% in 2002. Although the declining inflation trend continued into 2004, higher oil prices during 
the  second  half  of  the  year,  and  drought-related  increase  in  food  prices  are  exerting  upward 
pressure on inflation, which is likely to average around 7.2% by year end. In early November, 
the Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) raised key benchmark rates by 50 basis points in order to 
contain  inflationary  pressure  brought  on  by  the  combination  of  increasing  demand  on  the 
economy and the impact of higher oil prices on core inflation. The tightening of monetary policy 
is expected to signal the start of a tightening cycle in order to stabilize inflationary pressure. 
 
6. 
On  the  fiscal  side,  recent  developments  are  a  cause  for  concern.  Following  favorable 
fiscal consolidation in 2003—which resulted in a decline of the overall fiscal deficit from 8.9% in 
2002 to an estimated 7.5% in 2003—the fiscal stance has weakened in 2004. The slippage on 
the fiscal side is mainly attributed to some weakening in revenue performance, increased public 
spending,  as  well  as  the  effect  of  petroleum  price  subsidies  reflecting  the  surge  in  oil  prices 
during  the  year.  The  new  Government  has  yet  to  start  negotiations  with  the  International

Update: Sri Lanka. Manila. 

 2 

 

Monetary  Fund  (IMF)  on  a  new  Poverty  Reduction  and  Growth  Facility  (PRGF).  Some 
performance  criteria  and  structural  conditions  under  the  now  suspended  PRGF  were  not  met. 
The Government released its 2005 Budget on 18 November 2004 reflecting renewed efforts at 
strengthening revenues and curtailing expenditures. In line with the Government’s commitment 
to further fiscal consolidation, a reduction in the fiscal deficit is projected from a provisional level 
of 8.6% of GDP in 2004 to a level of 7.6% of GDP in 2005. 
 
7. 
High global oil prices are projected to increase the oil import bill from $800 million to $1.6 
billion  in  2004.  The  drain  on  foreign  currency  reserves  is  exacerbated  by  the  fact  that  some 
$300  million  of  anticipated  budget  support  from  development  partners  for  2004  will  not  be 
disbursed. The growing current account deficit which is now projected at around 4% of GDP, up 
from  0.6%  the  previous  year,  raised  volatility  of  the  exchange  rate.  The  Rupee  started  to 
depreciate  against  all  major  currencies,  in  contrast  to  last  year  when  the  Rupee  remained 
almost unchanged against the dollar. The Central Bank has spent some $550 million to support 
the currency, only in part being able to replenish its reserves which are now projected at about 
3.1 months of import cover. The Rupee depreciated by 8% in nominal terms against the dollar in 
the first 8 months of this year.  
 
8. 
Despite  the  challenges  to  macroeconomic  management,  particularly  resulting  from  the 
external  shocks  during  2004,  the  economic  outlook  in  Sri  Lanka  is  generally  favorable,  if  the 
domestic  imbalances,  notably  the  fiscal  deficit, are  adequately  addressed.  The  Government  is 
further  evolving  its  macroeconomic  program,  including  the medium  term  fiscal  program,  and  it 
has  committed  to  curtailing  fiscal  imbalances  by  introducing  measures  including  those  to 
improve  weak  revenue  performance.  If  revenue  augmentation  and  expenditure  rationalization 
measures  are  effectively  adopted,  the  medium-term  outlook  should  augur  well  for  sustained 
GDP  growth  at  5-6%  per  annum.  Otherwise,  mounting  fiscal  deficits  would  likely  exert  further 
upward  pressure  on  interest  rates,  weakening  the  local  currency  and  possibly  leading  to 
increasing inflation and lower growth. In the meantime, conventional leading indicators such as 
the stock market index continues on a bullish path with the Colombo Stock Exchange’s (CSE) 
All Share Price Index up by 44.8% in the first 10 months of 2004 and up by 88% since January 
2003. 
 
The Government’s medium-term development strategy, the Economic Policy Framework 
9. 
published  in  July  2004,  and  further  supported  by  the  2005  Budget,  focuses  on  key  areas 
including financial and capital markets reform, improvement of private sector access to finance, 
enhancement  of  small-  and  medium-  sized  enterprise  (SME)  growth,  and  the  reduction  of 
regional inequalities. Foreign investments beneficial to private sector development activities and 
technological advancement, as well as public-private partnerships in domestic resource based 
industries,  and  the  development  of  infrastructure  services  such  as  rural  telecommunications, 
electricity, and water supply schemes, are also being encouraged.  
 
10. 
To complement the Economic Policy Framework, the Government has established three 
major  agencies  in  May  2004,  reporting  directly  to  the  President  of  Sri  Lanka.  These  are  the 
National  Council  for  Economic  Development  (NCED)  to  oversee  and  steer  economic 
development policy; the Strategic Enterprise Management  Agency (SEMA)2 to restructure and 
eventually eliminate budgetary support of 12 strategic state-owned enterprises (SOEs) (the 12 

                                                 
2  SEMA has been established under a directive of the President by the powers vested in the President under Section 
33 of the Constitution. A SEMA Bill is being drafted and will be submitted to Parliament under the Program, which 
will ensure the independence of the strategic SOEs SEMA manages. 

  

 

3 

strategic  SOEs,  collectively,  Strategic  Enterprises),3  and  a  National  Procurement  Agency  to 
improve efficiency and encourage private sector participation in the procurement processes of 
the  Strategic  Enterprises.  The  remaining  nonstrategic  SOEs  will  be  overseen  by  the  existing 
Public Enterprise Reform Commission (PERC). 
 

 
Sector Description and Performance  

III. 

THE SECTOR 

1. 

The Private Sector and Small- and Medium-Sized Enterprises 

a. 

Private Sector 

11. 
The private sector in Sri Lanka is a principal source of investment and economic growth. 
In 2003, it accounted for an estimated 76% of aggregate investment, and consisted of 38,962 
registered  private  companies  and  2,236  registered  public  companies,  of  which  approximately 
75% were small- and medium-sized enterprises. The private sector had a dominant foothold in 
major  industries  such  as  food,  beverages,  textiles,  wood,  basic  metal,  nonmetallic  products, 
fabricated metal products, machinery and transport equipment, and manufactured products. The 
private sector employed about 44% of the workforce, up from 35% in 1990. If the self-employed 
and  unpaid  family  workers  were  included,  the  figure  would  rise  to  84%,  which  compared 
favorably with 77% in 1990. 
 
12. 
There is a sharp split in the profile of urban and rural enterprises. Urban enterprises are 
older  and  much  larger  than  their  rural  counterparts.  Large-scale  manufacturing  is  primarily 
export oriented and concentrated in the Colombo area, although geographical distribution differs 
markedly  across  sectors.  Rural  enterprises  are  likely  to  be  sole  proprietorships  headed  by  a 
male and based outside the home, established using household savings. The informal economy 
is quite large, estimated at about 45% of gross national income, compared with 35% average for 
the  rest  of  the  region,  and  16.8%  in  the  Organization  of  Economic  Co-operation  and 
Development (OECD) countries. 
 
Through  the  Private  Sector  Development  Program  (PSDP)  subprogram  I,4  the 
13. 
Government introduced a number of measures to stimulate private sector development. These 
include (i) the creation of the Consumer Affairs Authority, an autonomous agency to formulate 
and  enforce  consumer  protection  and  competition  policies;  (ii)  the  establishment  of  the 
Insurance Board of Sri Lanka (IBSL) as an independent regulator of insurance companies; (iii) 
the enhancement of the capital market through increasing the jurisdiction given to the Securities 
and  Exchange  Commission  (SEC)  by  broadening  its  regulatory  scope  in  securities-related 
industries  (i.e.,  underwriters,  margin  providers,  credit  rating  agencies,  investment  managers, 
and  clearing  houses);  (iv)  the  establishment  of  a  nationwide  job  counseling  network,  Jobsnet, 
dedicated to job placement and retraining of displaced workers; and (v) the implementation of a 
restructuring program for the state-owned savings bank, National Savings Bank.5

Water Supply and Drainage Board, and State Pharmaceutical Corporation.

The Government has recognized that the creation of a competitive and sound business 
14. 
environment  requires  an  autonomous  agency  for  formulation  and  enforcement  of  consumer 
protection  and  competition  policies.  To  this  end,  the  Consumer  Protection  Authority  Bill—
subsequently  renamed  the  CAA  Act—was  approved  by  Parliament  in  June  2003,  with 
responsibility  for  consumer  affairs  assigned  to  the  CAA  and  anti-trust  activities  under  the 
purview  of  the  Ministry  of  Justice.  Since  establishment,  the  CAA  has  been  reviewing  anti-
competition activities in certain industries and has been announcing stiff measures to eliminate 
cartel-like behavior in pricing certain consumer necessities. 
 
15.  With the gradual end of state monopolies and increase in private sector competition, a 
portion of Sri Lanka’s regulatory framework has been modernized. A multisector regulatory bill 
was enacted in September 2002 covering utilities, petroleum, power, and water, and a second 
bill  for  the  communications  industry  is  presently  being  drafted.  To  enhance  competition  in  the 
telecommunications  industry,  the  Sri  Lanka  Telecommunications  Ltd.’s  (SLTL)  monopoly  on 
telephony  services  was  eliminated  by  issuing  external  gateway  licenses  to  independent 
telephone operators. The Government also divested a majority of its shares in SLTL in 2003. As 
a result, Sri Lanka has one of Asia’s most liberalized telecommunications market. 
 
16. 
Sri  Lanka's  labor  policies  and  processes  are  relatively  rigid  by  international  standards 
and  are  perceived  to  have  been  creating  obstacles  to  the  expansion  of  private  labor  markets. 
Rigidities  have  included  the  legislation  on  involuntary  termination  for  nondisciplinary  staff 
reduction  and  lengthy  procedures  for  dispute  resolution.  The  Parliament  has  approved 
amendments  to  the  Termination  of  Employment  of  Workmen  Act  (TEWA)  for  involuntary 
termination of employment. The TEWA makes it mandatory for labor tribunal cases to be settled 
in  4  months,  arbitration  cases  in  2  months,  and  termination  cases  in  1  month.  Under  the 
amended TEWA, an employee will be entitled to a maximum of 1.5 months severance pay for 
36 months of employment. The amended TEWA eliminates the arbitrariness and uncertainty in 
labor retrenchment, and facilitates settlement of labor disputes. The Government is aware that 
full implementation will require availability of some type of unemployment insurance scheme for 
retrenched  workers,  which  could  prove  difficult  at  the  present  time  due  to  the  Government’s 
fiscal constraints. As part of social safety, more than 20 Jobsnet centers have been established 
providing  such  services  as  registration  of  job  seekers,  information  on  job  opportunities, 
matching  of  demand  and  supply  for  job  opportunities,  and  career  guidance.  A  summary  of 
accomplishments under PSDP subprogram I is in Supplementary Appendix B. 
 

b. 

Small- and Medium-Sized Enterprises 

17.  Most  of  Sri  Lanka's  SMEs  are  involved  in  production  (41%)  or  trading  (38%),  with  a 
smaller  proportion  in  service-related  activities  (21%).  Besides  manufacturing  processed 
agricultural goods, non-agricultural manufactured goods include garments, nonmetallic mineral 
products,  furniture,  and  wood  products.  In  the  trading  sector,  the  majority  of  enterprises  are 
engaged in selling processed (65%) and unprocessed agricultural products (57%). 

SMEs6 have a pivotal role in the private sector as well as in the overall economy. SMEs 
18. 
constitute  almost  95%  of  all  industrial  establishments.  According  to  the  most  recent  statistics 
available,  industrial  SMEs  are  still  only  responsible  for  35%  of  all  industrial  jobs  and  15%  of 
industry’s  value  added  to  the  economy.  SMEs  are  primarily  located  in  three  major  districts— 
Colombo, Gampaha, and Kalutara—with more than 40% of SMEs in Colombo alone. SMEs in 
these  three  districts  account  for  72%  of  total  employment  and  88%  of  total  SME  output.  The 

                                                 
6  Defined as enterprises with less than 100 employees. 

  

 

5 

results  of  a  recent  survey7  show  that  65%  of  SMEs  are  small  enterprises  while  the  remaining 
35% are of medium size.8 Of the small enterprises, 76% had assets in the range of $10,000–
50,000  indicating  that  there  are  many  very  small  enterprises  throughout  the  country,  most  of 
them sole proprietorships and/or partnerships. 

19. 
Sri  Lanka’s  SME  development  is  not  dynamic  in  terms  of  new  entrants  or  growth  of 
established  enterprises,  and  is  generally  constrained  by  weak  development  policies  that  favor 
large-scale industries, high transaction costs due to a complex tax regime, a weak skills base, 
and limited access to affordable financing. A well-functioning SME sector, however, would take 
the lead in generating jobs for economic growth and in raising income levels for a large segment 
of  the  low-income  population.  To  improve  the  policy  environment  for  SMEs  and  focus  on 
addressing  the  major  constraints  to  SME  development,  the  Government  has  established  an 
SME cluster committee within the NCED to coordinate activities that affect SMEs.  
 
Through  the  SME  Sector  Development  Program,9  several  policy  changes  were 
20. 
introduced to reduce the cost of operating and financing SMEs, primarily related to tax reform: 
rationalization  and  harmonization  of  tax  incentives.  These  reforms  included  the  reduction  of 
corporate  income  tax  for  SMEs,  abolition  of  turnover  tax  on  banking  and  financing  activities, 
harmonization  of  certain  tax  incentives,  and  the  abolition  of  stamp  duty  on  letters  of  credit. 
Commercial  legal  reforms  such  as  the  Bankruptcy  Act  are  underway,  to  provide  for  court-
supervised restructuring of enterprises in the event of financial default.  
 
21. 
The  Ministry  of  SME  Development  (MSMED)  has  the  responsibility  for  providing 
mechanisms for ongoing SME monitoring, developing long-term SME policy, and implementing 
regulatory  reforms.  It  has  established  five  centers  throughout  the  country  to  assist  SMEs  in 
obtaining  business  development  services  (BDS).10  BDS  include  outsourcing  activities  (e.g. 
payroll  and  accounting);  information  technology  services;  technical  services  (e.g.  design  and 
engineering); and finance brokering. A BDS registry has been developed to better match supply 
and demand in the local market for business support services. Entrepreneurs are able to identify 
and select relevant development services with the help of the registry. The registry includes all 
registered  BDS  organizations  in  Sri  Lanka  and  is  available  through  a  Government  web  site, 
developed under ADB assistance.  
 

2. 

Public Enterprises 

22. 
History. From independence in 1948 until 1977, Sri Lanka adopted a socialist approach 
to economic development. Starting from an economy that was primarily based on agriculture,11 
state-run enterprises were set up in a number of key sectors. State engagement in commercial

 6 

 

activities  supported  the  substitution  of  imports,  particularly  consumer  goods,  whose  entry  was 
regulated through tariff controls. By 1977, with the establishment of substantive state holdings in 
a  diverse  range  of  commercial  activities  across  agriculture,  industry,  finance,  and  physical 
infrastructure sectors, the state had been an imposing player in every sector of the economy. In 
1977,  policy  was  shifted.  State  planning  was  abandoned  and  economic  liberalization  policies 
were  explored  to  improve  international  competitiveness  and  encourage  private  sector 
involvement.  In  1991,  the  privatization  program  was  initiated  and  by  1996  the  liberalization 
process  was  accelerated  with  banking  reforms,  tax  reforms,  tariff  reforms,  and  incentives 
targeted to encourage foreign investment.  
 
23. 
As part of this process, Sri Lanka has made significant inroads in the sale of SOEs. Of 
Sri  Lanka’s  200  estimated  SOEs,  approximately  50%  have  been  privatized,  primarily 
plantations, and the manufacturing and services sectors. Since the beginning of 2001 (i.e. start 
of  implementation  of  PSDP  subprogram  I),  proceeds  from  the  sale  of  SOEs  have  been  in 
excess of $100 million. Proceeds from privatizations enabled the Government to retire a portion 
of its public debt.  
 
24. 
However,  there  has  been  a  negative  social  impact  of  privatization  on  workers, 
consumers,  and  the  public  in  general.  Labor  issues  became  significant  during  the  process 
because most SOEs were overstaffed as employment had been given under political patronage 
and, as a last resort, by the Government. There has been poor worker productivity as profit has 
not been the main goal in managing SOEs. At the time of privatization, the Government faced 
critical questions as to how to handle the issue of surplus labor. Although redundancies in some 
SOEs could be as high as 50%, voluntary retirement schemes (VRS) have run into difficulties 
including  assessing  who  is  redundant,  and  how  much  they  should  be  compensated  to  retire 
voluntarily. Also, a lack of a clear Government direction on VRS led to ad hoc packages whose 
value rest mainly on the bargaining power of the unions. In some instances, the VRS were so 
attractive that more than the anticipated number of employees left the SOEs.  
 
25. 
Apart  from  the  employment  issues,  social  effects  of  privatization  were  also  felt  by 
consumers via price increases, poorer quality products, and reduction or elimination of essential 
services such as bus transportation in unprofitable rural areas. 
 
26. 
Strategic Enterprises. Some of the larger Strategic Enterprises depend on Government 
financial support thereby creating a burden on the budget. By the end of 2003, five12 of the 12 
Strategic Enterprises had received capital injections from the Government in an amount equal to 
SLRs16.6  billion  ($158  million).  In  2004,  the  estimated  capital  injections  total  SLRs11.3  billion 
($108 million). To compound the situation, state-owned banks have been financing unprofitable 
SOEs, resulting in a weakened banking system. Unlike former governments, the strategy of the 
present  Government  is  to  be  responsible  for  restructuring  Strategic  Enterprises  and improving 
their profitability and corporate governance rather than privatizing them.  
 
SEMA13  was  created  to  manage  Strategic  Enterprises  as  independent  commercial 
27. 
enterprises,  free  from  political  interference.  The  Strategic  Enterprises  have  combined  total 
assets  of  over  $10.5  billion  and  approximately  125,000  employees.  The  Strategic  Enterprises 
include four banks (People’s Bank [PBank], Bank of Ceylon [BOC], National Savings Bank, and 
                                                 
12 The Ceylon Electricity Board, the National Water Supply and Drainage Board, Sri Lanka Railways, the Airports and 

Aviation Authority, and the Sri Lanka Central Transport Board. 

13 The  former  government  was  planning  to  form  a  holding  company  to  manage  the  five  largest  state-owned 
companies in Sri Lanka, as discussed in ADB. 2003. Progress Report on the Private Sector Development Program

7 

State  Mortgage  and  Investment  Bank),  two  energy  suppliers  (Ceylon  Electricity  Board  and 
Ceylon Petroleum Corporation), four transportation providers (Sri Lanka Ports Authority, Airports 
and  Aviation  Authority,  Sri  Lanka  Railways  and  the  Sri  Lanka  Central  Transport  Board);  the 
National  Water  Supply  and  Drainage  Board;  and  the  State  Pharmaceutical  Corporation.  Since 
SEMA’s establishment, the Government has been committed to ensuring that the line ministries 
have roles in formulating policy, but that line ministries do not give operational directions to the 
Strategic Enterprises.  
 
To  improve  profitability,  each  of  the  Strategic  Enterprises  has  or  will  submit  to  SEMA 
28. 
restructuring plans approved by the respective board. The restructuring plans have been or are 
being  submitted  for  consideration  for  the  Cabinet’s  approval.  Each  of  the  restructuring  plans 
shall contain strict budget ceilings to reduce the Strategic Enterprises' impact on public finances 
and to prevent state-owned banks from financing their losses. 
 
SEMA's objectives14 for each of the Strategic Enterprises include (i) improving efficiency, 
29. 
effectiveness,  and  financial  viability  through  appropriate  supervision;  (ii)  ensuring  commercial 
and political independence of board members; (iii) ensuring effective management through the 
boards of directors, a majority of the members representing the private sector; (iv) establishing 
industrial  benchmarks  and  regional  standards  to  be  achieved  over  the  next  3–5  years;  (v) 
obtaining an initial credit rating from a credit rating institute, and improving that rating over time; 
(vi) motivating management to effectively compete in the relevant market while being mindful of 
the  expectations  of  the  general  public  and  social  welfare;  and  (vii)  ensuring  that  approved 
restructuring plans will be implemented according to schedule.  
 
Strategic Enterprises will be encouraged by SEMA to focus on their core businesses. As 
30. 
a result, the restructuring plans envisage them to (i) rationalize their assets by either disposing 
of  idle  (non-core)  assets  as  well  as  entering  into  public-private  partnership  arrangements  for 
financing  new  projects  and/or  related  services;  and  (ii)  outsource  certain  services which  could 
be  provided  less  expensively  and/or  with  greater  quality  than  internally    (e.g.  treasury,  fund 
management, human resources development, and marketing). 
 
31. 
A general recruitment ban that had been placed on SOEs over the past few years has 
been lifted for Strategic Enterprises. They will be able to recruit qualified managers as outlined 
in  their  approved  restructuring  plans.  The  Cabinet  will  also  approve  a  VRS  to  retrench 
nonessential  employees  for  a  Strategic  Enterprises  if  (i)  the  VRS  meets  the  objectives  of  the 
approved restructuring plan, and (ii) there are sufficient funds to implement the VRS based upon 
the restructuring plan approved by the board of directors of the Strategic Enterprises. 
 

3. 

Financial Markets 

 In Sri Lanka, the financial markets primarily consist of banks, insurance companies, and 
32. 
provident funds. The financial sector is dominated by state-owned institutions, that control more 
than  60%  of  the  total  assets  held  by  all  financial  institutions  in  the  country.  The  contractual 
savings institutions especially the state-owned Employees Provident Fund, the Employees Trust 
Fund,  and  private  provident  funds  are  also  significant  in  terms  of  assets  under  management, 
and accounted for about 20% of total assets. An overview of the financial markets is contained 
in Supplementary Appendix C. 

                                                 
14 The rights and responsibilities of Strategic Enterprise Management Agency (SEMA) will be formalized in the SEMA 

Act. The introduction of the SEMA Bill to Parliament is a second-tranche release condition of the Program. 

 8 

 

Banks.  The  institutional  structure  of  the  banking  market  defies  easy  description.  It 
33. 
reflects  a  long  history  of  the  Government  establishing  special-purpose  institutions  to  provide 
specific  legal  powers  to  meet  identified  needs.  Competition  in  the  banking  sector  is  based  on 
products and geographic location, not the type of institution. There are 22 commercial banks, 42 
depository  institutions  (a  national  savings  bank,  24  finance  companies,  and  17  regional  rural 
development  banks),  three  state-sponsored  long-term  financial  institutions,  11  insurance 
companies,  and  two  public  pension  funds.  The  licensed  commercial  banks  and  the  licensed 
specialized banks accounted for 79% of the assets of financial sector assets in 2003.  
 
34. 
The Banking Act No. 30 of 1988 and its subsequent amendments are the main pieces of 
legislation that govern the conduct of the banking institutions in Sri Lanka. The Monetary Law 
Act establishes the CBSL. The CBSL regulates, supervises, and monitors the banking industry, 
and the leasing and finance companies. 
 
35. 
Insurance Companies. There were 13 insurance companies at the end 2003, of which 
two are engaged in life insurance. The others were engaged in both life and general insurance. 
After  the  Government  divested  its  90%  stake  in  the  Sri  Lanka  Insurance  Corporation  Ltd.  in 
2003,  almost  the  entire  insurance  industry  became  privately  held.  The  total  asset  base  of  the 
industry  grew  by  10%  and  was  SLRs61  billion  ($582  million)  at  end-2003.  The  average  life 
insurance penetration (premium as a percentage of GDP) is 0.6%, which is low by international 
standards  (i.e.  2.2–3.6%  for  emerging  countries  and  5.4–8.4%  for  industrialized  countries), 
indicating a potential for expansion in the industry. 
 
36. 
Stock  Market.  The  stock  indexes  have  recorded  significant  gains  since  2001.  The  All 
Share Price Index increased by more than  70% during the 2-year period ended 31 December 
2003. The Sri Lankan equity market has remained fairly small, despite a relatively long period of 
existence.  Some  241  companies  are  listed  on  the  Colombo  Stock  Exchange  (CSE), 
representing 20 business sectors. Market capitalization remains comparatively low at SLRs263 
billion  ($2.5  billion)  or  about  16%  of  GDP  as  of  December  2003.  As  a  result  of  the  ceasefire, 
foreign investors were net buyers at the CSE for almost three consecutive years.  
 
37. 
Government  and  Corporate  Debt  Securities  Market.  Government  debt  securities 
dominate  Sri  Lanka’s  debt  market,  representing  98%  of  the  total  value  of  issued  debentures. 
Until recently, there has been no market based yield curve because primary government issues 
were  sold  at  below  market  rates  to  state-owned  institutions.  The  market  is  therefore  large  but 
illiquid.  The  maximum  maturity  of  most  sovereign  bonds  is  5–7  years.  Since  1997,  certain 
corporate bonds have also been listed on the CSE, but such instruments are almost illiquid. The 
market  capitalization  of  listed  corporate  debt  is  small,  totaling  SLRs9.7  billion  (approximately 
$93 million) in December 2003. 
 
A number of legislative enactments relating to the financial sector are being drafted (e.g. 
38. 
the  Bankruptcy  Act,  amendments  to  the  Securities  and  Exchange  Commission  [SEC]  Act, 
Banking Act, and Amendments to the Companies Act) in order to improve regulatory oversight 
and  facilitate  greater  competition  in  the  financial  markets  while  keeping  abreast  of  market 
developments.  However,  reforms  should  be  made  to  further  strengthen  the  resiliency  of  the 
financial system and improve the depth and scope of the financial markets.  
 
 
 
 

  

 

9 

Issues and Opportunities 

1. 

Development of Financial Markets 

 
Debt  Market.  For  the  private  sector  to  participate  actively  in  economic  activities,  it 
39. 
should have adequate access to finance at appropriate rates and terms. The ongoing study on 
the  Sri  Lanka  Investment  Climate15  highlights  finance,  together  with  the  poor  quality  of 
infrastructure,  as  the  major  obstacle  for  urban  and  rural  enterprises.  The  private  sector  faces 
difficulties accessing finance in Sri Lanka because the Government uses more than 50% of the 
country's  financial  resources  to  fund  the  fiscal  deficit.  As  of  year-end  2003,  Government 
borrowings  were  approximately  $10.2  billion,  representing  106%  of  GDP  and  accounting  for 
approximately 98% of the total debt market value. CBSL, through the Monetary Board, is solely 
responsible  for  issuing  public  debt  and  the  principal  investors  in  government  securities  are 
state-owned  institutions.  Until  recently,  government  bonds  were  not  issued  through  the  price 
discovery  method,16  and  as  a  result,  the  bonds  were  sold  at  below  market  rates,  primarily  to 
state-owned  institutions.  To  prevent  losses,  almost  all  investors  hold  bonds  to  maturity.  As  a 
consequence, although the Government security market is large, there is no active trading, and 
until  recently,  there  was  no  true  market  yield  curve.  Additionally,  the  maximum  maturity  for 
bonds is 5-7 years. Longer term financing should be available to rebuild the infrastructure after 
20  years  of  civil  conflict.  Moreover,  due  to  the  absence  of a  long-term  government  bond  yield 
curve and accompanied by certain tax issues, the corporate bond market remains small. Also, 
certain  technical  and  legal  issues  prevent  alternative  financial  instruments  to  be  introduced  in 
the debt market.  
 
Equity  Investment.  The  CSE  has  existed  since  1896,  but  remains  small  and  illiquid. 
40. 
Investment interest in the equity market must increase to provide the necessary risk capital to 
the  country  (only  3.2%  of  private  sector  investment  capital  was  raised  through  initial  public 
offerings  in the  CSE  in  2003).  International  best  practice  standards  should  be  implemented  to 
attract  more  investment  capital  to  the  CSE.  Appropriate  modern  information  technology  is 
needed to ensure that the clearing of equity securities is enhanced to reduce settlement risk to 
sellers and buyers of publicly traded shares.  
 
Institutional  Investors.  Assets  of  institutional  investors  amount  to  approximately  one 
41. 
third of total bank assets. Despite this large amount of assets, their impact on financial market 
development and innovation through new products have been negligible, mainly because they 
have been used as a captive source for funding primarily government debt. Private companies 
funding needs are largely met internally, or for larger enterprises, from commercial banks. 
 
42. 
Capital  Market.  If  necessary  reforms  were  made  in  both  the  debt  and  equity  markets, 
including  the  introduction  of  new  financial  products  and  services  to  manage  risk,  a  better 
functioning  capital  market  would  develop,  which  should  attract  more  investors  and  issuers, 
thereby  increasing  competition  in  the  banking  industry,  which  should  have  a  positive  effect  of 
reducing  financial  intermediation  costs17  (average  interest  rate  spreads  for  commercially 
licensed banks were over 4% in 2003).

accommodate the financing needs of a large portion of the private sector and serves mostly the

only 30% of BOC's and 37% of PBank's loan portfolio, such loans account for the bulk of their 
nonperforming loans.  
 
44.  Most other banks, including private ones, also suffer from high levels of nonperforming 
loans,  inadequate  provisioning,  heavy  reliance  on  collateral  security,  and  high  cost/income 
ratios. Banks’ interest rate spreads remain high although there has been an overall reduction of 
interest rates. Because there is little competition, private banks take advantage of state banks’ 
high  operating  costs  to  charge  similarly  high  rates  of  interest  to  their  borrowers.  Until  weak 
banks (state-owned and private) are restructured or exit the market, competition will be limited 
and margins will remain high. 
 
Legal  System  Foreclosure.  The  legal  system  has  also  been  ineffective  in  protecting 
45. 
creditors’ interests. Although certain laws have been introduced to strengthen creditors’ rights18 
to recover loans and advances, borrowers have been successful in obtaining injunctions against  
recovery  efforts  from  banks,  resulting  in  a  burden  of  non-performing  loans  on  banks’  balance 
sheets. 
 

a. 

Required Improvement in Financial Products and Services Available 
to the Capital Market 

 
46.  Mortgage Financing. At the end of 2003, the mortgage market was worth $220 million. 
Within  a  relatively  short  time,  as  a  result  of  the  ceasefire,  the  demand  for  home  mortgage 
financing had grown rapidly. New housing loans in 2003 grew by $80 million. Traditionally, the 
Government has supplied 20–25% of all home mortgage financing. The system is not viable in 
the longer term because the Government is reluctant to foreclose on defaulted borrowers and 
has  a  limited  budget  to  finance  the  increased  demand  in  mortgage  financing.  Mortgage 
financing provided by commercial banks, and to a limited extent, mortgage banks is offered in 
tenors  of  15  to  20  years.  However,  interest  rates  are  high  (approximately  13%)  because  of 
financial  risks  resulting  from  a  mismatch  of  funding  long-term  fixed  rate  mortgage  loans  with 
short-term variable rate deposits.  
 
Like  most  developing  countries,  Sri  Lanka  suffers  from  a  significant  housing  shortage. 
47. 
The  country  currently  lacks  400,000  housing  units,  and  that  number  is  set  to  increase  to 
approximately 650,000 units by 2010. A large proportion of the existing housing is substandard 
and  lack  essential  amenities.  Because  mortgage  financing  is  unattractive,  there  are  few  new 
housing  starts.  Private  sector  housing  construction  could  be  an  increasingly  important 
contribution to economic growth. Improved mortgage financing is necessary to improve housing 
standards  and  provide  jobs.  An  alternative  financing  method,  such  as  the  issuance  of 
securitized bonds secured by mortgage receivables, could substantially improve the amount of 

                                                 
18 Parate rights are granted by law to commercial banks and other specialized banks. In the case of default, parate 

rights give these institutions a right to quickly repossess collateralized property. 

  

 

11 

funds  available  for  financing  home  mortgages,  as  well  as  improve  interest  rates  offered  for 
mortgage financing. 
 
48. 
Financing  Movable  Property.  Sri  Lankan  banks  are  providing  financing  primarily 
against collateral in the form of fixed assets and/or personal guarantees. However, banks do not 
readily finance movable assets such as computers and industrial equipment because they risk 
not  finding  the  collateral  in  the  event  of  default.  Registries  for  movable  property  exist  in  Sri 
Lanka  but  are  many  and  disbursed  throughout  the  country:  each  district  has  its  own  registry, 
making  it  difficult  for  banks  to  keep  track  of  pledged  collateral  nationwide.  The  private  sector 
and  SMEs,  in  particular,  need  financing  for  movable  property.  If  a  national  registry  were 
established, banks would be more receptive to providing financing secured by movable assets. 
A  national  movable  property  registry  needs  to  be  developed  to  replace  the  present 
decentralized ad hoc system.  
 
49. 
Equity  Market.  Since  the  ceasefire  took  effect,  the  CSE  has  increased  its  market 
capitalization and trading volume. Still, the products and services offered are limited, especially 
in  the  area  of  risk  management.  Most  shares  listed  on  the  CSE  are  not  actively  traded.  To 
attract  more  domestic  and  foreign  investors  who  could  provide  capital  to  the  country,  investor 
confidence  should  be  strengthened  by  improving  corporate  governance  through  establishing 
international best practice standards of corporate governance.  
 
50. 
Equity  Trading  Settlement  Cycle.  The  main  responsibility  of  the  Central  Depository 
System  is  to  support  settlement  of  traded  securities  and  to  minimize  the  settlement  risk. 
Standard international equity settlement requirements require (i) final settlement cycle to occur 
no later than the trade date plus 3 days (T+3); and (ii) payment for securities to occur only on 
delivery of securities to the buyer (i.e. delivery versus payment [DVP]).  The Sri Lankan equity 
settlement system has a cycle equal to the trade date plus 6 days (T+6) and there is no DVP 
system, resulting in buyers and sellers of Sri Lankan equities taking more financial and market 
exposure risks when compared with other international markets. 
 
51.  Mutual  Funds.  By  the  end  of  2003,  total  assets  under  management  of  the  12 
established mutual funds amounted to approximately $36 million. Although mutual funds are in 
a position to provide investors with the benefits of diversification, the industry has not been able 
to  grow  quickly  enough.  Factors  limiting  the  growth  of  the  mutual  funds  industry  include  high 
volatility  in  the  equity  market,  a  narrow  range  of  instruments  to  manage  financial  risks,  and 
unfavorable  tax  treatment  (i.e.  double  taxation  resulting  from  taxes  paid  on  interest  and/or 
dividend  income  by  the  mutual  fund,  and  capital  gains  tax  paid  on  the  mutual  fund  by  the 
investor). Improving the tax treatment for mutual funds should attract smaller investors to invest 
in  mutual  funds,  particularly,  money  market  mutual  funds,  which  will  have  on  overall  positive 
effect on the bond market. 
 

b. 

Enhanced Corporate Governance in the Financial Markets 

 
52. 
Issuance  and  Sale  of  Public  Debt.  CBSL  is  responsible  for  developing  and 
implementing  monetary  policy.  However,  the  Monetary  Board,  which  reports  to  CBSL,  is 
responsible for issuing and selling all public debt. This results in a conflict of interest with CBSL 
when the Monetary Board is ascertaining the amount, timing, and maturity of issued securities. 
The  responsibility  for  developing  and  implementing  monetary  policy  should  be  completely 
independent from the issuance and sale of public debt. In so doing, the pricing of government 
debt will be more transparent and a true market yield curve will develop.  
 

 12 

 

Increased Supervision of the Financial Regulators. The SEC regulates the securities 
53. 
market,  as  well  as  licensing  the  CSE  and  its  broker  members  while  the  CBSL  fundamentally 
regulates  banks.  However,  there  are  a  number  of  smaller  nonregulated  financial  entities 
fraudulently  issuing  or  selling  securities  or  other  interests  to  the  general  public  and  that  are 
outside  the  realm  of  the  financial  regulators  (SEC,  CBSL,  CSE,  and  Insurance  Board  of  Sri 
Lanka  [IBSL]).  In  effect,  this  allows  such  entities  to  issue  securities  and  interests  and  employ 
other  means  of  raising  finance  without  the  oversight  of  the  regulators,  posing  a  risk  to  the 
stability  of  the  financial  system.  Regulating  agencies  need  to  be  given  the  legal  power  and 
authority to take action against fraudulent financial schemes. 
 
54. 
Independence of SEC. The SEC Act provides that the majority of SEC commissioners 
(7 of 10) including the chairman, be appointed by the Ministry of Finance and Planning (MOFP). 
However,  from  the  point  of  view  of  international  best  practice,  the  regulator  should  be 
operationally  independent  from  external  political  or  commercial  interference  and  be  held  fully 
accountable in the exercise of its powers and functions. 
 
Corporate Governance Code. To improve corporate governance of listed securities on 
55. 
the  CSE,  the  SEC  should  issue  a  regulation  or  directive  making  it  mandatory  for  listed 
companies to use a code of best practice for corporate governance19 following international best 
practice standards. Mandatory corporate governance provisions should be adopted to improve 
investor confidence in the financial markets.  
 
56. 
Prevention of Money Laundering. IMF has been providing technical assistance (TA) to 
Sri Lanka to avoid Sri Lanka’s financial system being used for money laundering activities. The 
Anti-Money Laundering Bill needs to be introduced to Parliament. 
 

c. 

Improved Regulations of the Insurance Industry 

Since 2001, the regulation of the insurance industry has been brought under the IBSL.20 
57. 
While IBSL is an independent entity, it currently operates within the SEC, with most of its staff 
being  utilized  on  a  shared  basis.  Given  its  short  history,  under-staffing  and  lack  of  a  board  of 
directors,  IBSL  does  not  function  properly  as  a  regulator.  The  insurance  industry  manages 
roughly one third of the total assets in the financial market. Many of the insurance companies 
lack financial strength and some may be in danger of meeting required financial coverage and 
reserve ratios. The first step in making the IBSL operational is to appoint a board of directors. 
Also,  IBSL’s  capacity  must  be  improved  in  order  to  monitor  and  supervise  the  insurance 
insurance  companies  comply  with  prudential  requirements,  and  meet 
industry,  have 
international best practice standards.  
 
58. 
Because  there  are  few  long-term  financial  products  in  the  debt  market,  life  insurance 
companies face significant portfolio risks since they are unable to match the maturities of their 
investment  with  the  liabilities  in  their  portfolios  (e.g.  investments,  on  average,  have  maturities 
with  3–5  years  while liability  of  life insurance companies  have  maturities  with  20  to  30  years). 
Although life insurance companies have long-term liabilities, they have not become a significant 
institutional investor group providing the much-needed capital for infrastructure investments and 
sustainable growth. Insurance companies should be permitted to invest in securitized bonds.

2. 

Operational Improvement of State-Owned Commercial Banks 

BOC and PBank were  established through Acts of Parliament.21 Under these Acts, the 
59. 
Government  has  the  power  to  appoint  boards  of  directors,  to  issue  instructions,  and  to  give 
general or special directions which is the duty that the boards must comply with. Management is 
formally constrained from making independent commercial decisions on credit, terms of loans, 
interest  rates,  recruitment,  salaries,  and  employee  incentives.  During  the  past  4  years,  the 
banks  have  been  managed  independently,  but  the  BOC  and  PBank  Acts  need  to  be  formally 
amended to ensure the commercial and political independence of the boards and management.  
 
60. 
People’s  Bank.  PBank,  one  of  the  12  Strategic  Enterprises  managed  by  SEMA,  was 
established  in  1961  to  develop  the  cooperative  movement  of  Sri  Lanka  and  enhance  rural 
banking.  Presently,  the  Government  owns  92%  of  PBank  and  the  Sri  Lankan  Cooperative 
Societies  own  the  remaining  8%.  Based  upon  assets  of  SLRs206  billion  (approximately  $2 
billion)  as  of  end-2003,  PBank  has  a  market  share  of  over  22%,  and  is  Sri  Lanka’s  second 
largest  bank.  Through  its  325  branches,  the  largest  banking  network  in  the  country,  PBank 
provides  such  services  as  corporate  banking,  SME  financing,  trade  finance,  and  retail  and 
consumer finance. Approximately 50% of PBank’s branches serve rural areas. PBank employs 
more than 10,000 people.  
 
SME  financing  and  corporate/commercial  banking  account  for  approximately  16%  and 
61. 
40% of the loan portfolio, respectively. Of the total corporate/commercial lending, 24% are total 
advances  net  of  provisioning  to  SOEs  or  to  borrowers  guaranteed  by  the  Government.  As  a 
result of the bank’s relatively large exposure to pawn brokerage (25% of the loan portfolio) and 
its  significant  branch  network,  PBank  has  a  large  deposit  base  that  provides  PBank  with 
inexpensive funding. However, its exposure to consumer lending is low, representing only 10% 
of  the  loan  portfolio.  PBank  needs  to  avail  itself  of  low-cost  funding  by  increasing  consumer 
lending  and  thereby  improve  its  profitability.  PBank  also  provides  lease  financing  through  its 
subsidiaries. Although leasing represents only 0.3% of PBank’s total loan portfolio, it is one of 
the  bank’s  more  profitable  business  areas  (approximately  13%  of  consolidated  income).  Real 
estate development and corporate finance are other small business areas. 
 
Poor  management  over  a  period  of  time,  characterized  by  high  operating  costs  and 
62. 
politically  influenced  lending  practices,  resulted  in  poor  asset  quality  and  poor  credit  culture 
severely  impacting  PBank's  financial  profile.  In  1993  and  1996,  the  Government  recapitalized 
PBank  (SLRs10.5  billion  in  1993  and  SLRs10.0  billion  in  1996).  These  capital  injections  were 
not accompanied by any restructuring of PBank so the financial deterioration did not stop.  
 
63. 
Past Performance. Substantive changes were made in 1999 to depoliticize PBank. New 
board members were appointed from the private sector. Top management, also from the private 
sector  and  with  significant  international  banking  experience,  was  hired  in  2001,  significantly 
reducing  political  influence  on  bank  management  and  operations.  The  new  management 
decided to restructure PBank and introduce substantial operational improvements by preparing 
and  implementing  a  strategic  plan  (2001–2003)  (Strategic  Plan).  Such  measures  included 
reducing  the  cost  structure,  introducing  risk  management  techniques,  and  ensuring  sharper 
customer focus.

The most notable improvement was in net profit after tax, which substantially surpassed 
65. 
the forecasts and improved more than 500% within the 3-year period, lowering the cost/income 
ratio from 89% to 70%. The return on assets also improved significantly to 0.81%, which is over 
2.5 times the forecasted result outlined in the Strategic Plan. Also, during the 3–year period, the 
negative  net  worth  of  the  bank  has  been  reduced  from  SLRs6.9  billion  to  SLRs4  billion,  the 
return  on  assets  has  improved  from  0.18%  to  0.81%,  loan-loss  provision  cover  has  increased
