66. 
The  highlights  of  the  Strategic  Plan  of  2001–2003  included  (i)  debt  recovery  and 
stringent credit evaluation procedures; (ii) deposit mobilization, resulting in increased customer 
base to 9 million people and improved deposit base by 23% to $1.6 billion; (iii) increased focus 
on and improved commercial lending, resulting in loans and advances improving by over $100 
million  to  $958  million  during  the  period  (i.e.  PBank’s  smaller  branches  have  not  been 
successful  at  increasing  commercial  lending,  and  their  business  focus  and  size  needs  to  be 
readjusted);  (iv)  increased  focus  on  human  resources,  including  an  improvement  in  customer 
service;  (v)  entering  into  an  agreement  with  an  information  technology  service  provider  to 
automate  the  branch  network  with  headquarters;  (vi)  upgrading  the  pawning  branches;  (vii) 
improving treasury operations; and (viii) becoming a primary dealer for government securities. 
 
67. 
For the 9 months ended 30 September 2004, profit was SLRs2.1 billion, representing an 
increase  of  16%  from  the  prior  year.  Cost/income  ratio  was  70%.  Total  deposits  increased  to 
SLRs175.6 billion, an increase of 14.3% from the previous year, while total loans and advances 
increased to SLRs112.4 billion, an impressive increase of almost 20% from the prior year. The 
major accomplishments in 2004 to date include (i) identification of 45 branches that will focus on 
improving  commercial  lending;  (ii)  increased  home  mortgage  loans  to  SLRs1  billion  (up  more 
than 100% compared to 2003); (iii) increased pawning advances to over SLRs3 billion; and (iv) 
outsourced over 200 jobs, thereby reducing staff costs.  
 
68. 
Rationale  of  Restructuring  PBank.  Management  is  continuing  to  implement  the 
restructuring plan. However, PBank had a negative net worth of $40 million at year-end 2003. 

                                                 
22 People's Bank historical income statements and balance sheets are contained in Supplementary Appendix D. 

  

 

15 

The core issue confronting PBank impinges on its sustained viability and its capital deficit. As a 
result  of  not  meeting  the  prudential  regulations  of  a  minimum  capital  adequacy  ratio  (CAR) 
required  to  operate  as  a  bank,  the  bank  is  operating  under  a  Letter  of  Comfort  from  the 
Government. There are macroeconomic and macro-political issues that require the Government 
to restructure PBank and to make it viable: (i) PBank has the widest branch distribution network 
servicing the rural sector across the entire country while other licensed commercial banks have 
limited  or  no  representation  in  the  rural  area;  and  (ii)  by  not  strictly  enforcing  the  minimum 
required  CAR  requirements,  the  Government  and  CBSL  are  sending  a  message  to  other 
commercial  banks  that  it  will  tolerate  non-compliance  with  prudential  regulations.  Fiscal 
discipline  and  sound  banking  practices  are  necessary  signals  that  must  be  given  from  the 
Government and CBSL to the banking sector. 
 

3. 

Lessons Learned 

69. 
Cluster Modality. PSDP was approved as a cluster program. Because of the uncertain 
security situation resulting from the civil war and the large public debt at the time of the design 
of PSDP design, caution was exercised to avoid adding pressure to the public budget or placing 
additional demands that could disrupt economic stability and growth. As a result, the PSDP was 
structured as a cluster with two subprograms.  
 
PSDP subprogram I covered a broad range of political, social, economic, and financial 
70. 
issues and reforms affecting the public and private sectors; investment in various infrastructure 
projects,  financial  markets  (i.e.  banks,  pensions,  insurance,  and  the  capital  markets), 
regulations  (e.g.  labor,  competition,  and  financial  market  governance);  and  skills  efficiency. 
Such  an  ambitious  program  covering  a  broad  spectrum  of  reforms  proved  quite  difficult  to 
implement especially since it covered politically sensitive issues (i.e. labor issues and pension 
reform). The proposed Program will focus on a narrower area of private sector development that 
is prioritized by the Government.  
 
71. 
Care  should  also  be  taken  when  designing  a  program  as  a  cluster.  Although  PSDP 
subprogram  I  was  scheduled  for  completion  within  2  years,  it  took  more  than  3  years  to 
implement.  Within  that  time,  two  elections  were  held  and  significant  changes  occurred  in  the 
Government, parties, approaches, and economic strategies. Moreover, policy reforms originally 
envisaged in the PSDP for support under a subprogram II were increasingly addressed by other 
donors.  The  World  Bank,  notably,  has  increasingly  focused  on  supporting  policy  reforms  such 
as reforms for private pension and provident funds, and the unemployment insurance schemes 
that were envisaged under subprogram II. The IMF has continued to provide assistance to the 
banking  industry.  The  Development  Coordination  Matrix  is  included  in  Appendix  2.  Moreover, 
increasingly,  the  focus  of  ADB  assistance  by  other  departments  in  various  sectors,  such  as 
power  and  transport,  have  been  on  policy,  legal,  and  regulatory  framework  as  well  as  on 
facilitating  private  sector  participation  in  infrastructure.  As  a  result,  the  indicative  scope  of  the 
PSDP  (subprogram  II)  as  originally  envisaged  deviates  quite  noticeably  from  the  refocused 
scope under the proposed Program. This issue is explained more fully and included in Appendix 
1. 
 
72. 
Recapitalization of People’s Bank. People’s Bank has been recapitalized in 1993 and 
1996.  The  recapitalizations  were  provided  by  the  Government  without  a  requirement  to 
implement  a  restructuring  plan  to  improve  the  financial  viability  of  PBank.  However,  the 
proposed  Program  is  designed  to  provide  a  phased-in  recapitalization  of  PBank,  when 
performance  targets  are  met  on  an  agreed  time  schedule  contained  in  the  restructuring  plan. 

 16 

 

Additionally,  the  amount  of  the  recapitalization  to  be  provided  will  only  be  sufficient  to  meet 
minimum CAR requirements. 
 

IV. 

THE PROPOSED PROGRAM 

73. 
The PSDP loan to the Government, approved by ADB in December 2000, adopted the 
program cluster approach with two subprograms: subprogram I and subprogram II. Subprogram 
I was in an amount equivalent to $100 million, for disbursement in three tranches. The third and 
final tranche of subprogram I was released in November 2003. 
 
74. 
Subprogram  II  was  to  be  based  on  the  implementation  progress  of  subprogram  I,  with 
policy  actions  subject  to  revision  depending  on  ADB’s  reassessment  of  the  macroeconomic 
environment, lessons learned during subprogram I, and status of implementation and readiness 
of  the  Government  to  undertake  proposed  policy  reform  actions.23  Accordingly,  the  scope  of 
subprogram  II  has  been  refocused  (para.  71).  In  particular,  financial  sector  development  has 
been broadened to further facilitate access to finance by the private sector, including SMEs. The 
restructuring of a state-owned bank has also been focused on through the enhancement of the 
efficiency and financial soundness of PBank. The Government’s development policy letter, key 
reform areas, and the specific time-bound actions are defined in the policy matrix (Appendix 3) 
and  the  program  framework  (Appendix  4).  A  description  of  the  policy  reform  program  of  the 
Program follows. 
 
Objective and Scope 

As  indicated  in  the  Economic  Policy  Framework  announced  in  July  2004,  the 
75. 
Government’s reforms will focus on restructuring Strategic Enterprises to become more efficient 
and  profitable,  creating  a  balance  between  private  and  public  interests,  and  improving  the 
institutional and regulatory framework for the private sector, particularly SMEs. As highlighted in 
ADB’s  Country  Strategy  and  Program  Update  (2005–2006),  ADB  will  continue  to  assist  the 
Government  in  providing  support  to  financial  markets  and  private  sector  development,  its 
stronger, renewed focus on SMEs, and promoting growth in the rural areas through policy and 
institutional reforms.  
 
76. 
The proposed Program seeks to facilitate participation by private businesses, including 
SMEs,  in  the  Sri  Lankan  economy.  The  Program  aims  to  do  so  by  supporting  government 
reforms  to  eliminate  impediments  to  and  develop  opportunities  for  greater  private  sector 
involvement in the economy. Although the country is experiencing economic growth, most of it is 
being generated from larger enterprises located in industrial areas. The Program aims to create 
a private sector that takes a lead in generating employment, boosting the economic growth and 
raising incomes for a larger segment of the population, including those in rural areas. 
 
77. 
The  principal  objective  of  the  Program  is  to  facilitate  private  sector  development  by 
strengthening  the  financial  markets,  including  the  restructuring  and  phased  recapitalization  of 
PBank.  The  Program  comprises  a  policy  loan  and  a  TA  loan.  The  scope  of  the  policy  loan 
includes (i) development of financial markets through (a) increasing the availability of financial 
products  and  services  to  the  financial  market;  (b)  enhancing  corporate  governance  in  the 
financial market; (c) improving insurance industry regulation; and (ii) strengthening the banking 
system through (a) improving corporate governance of state-owned commercial banks, and (b) 

                                                 
23 See Loan and Program Summary section, p. iii, in the Report and Recommendation of the President on the Private 

Sector Development Program in Sri Lanka (Loans 1800 and 1801). November 2000. 

  

 

17 

restructuring  the  state-owned  PBank.  The  Program,  in  the  longer  term,  will  enhance  the 
availability of financial alternatives, reduce overall financing costs, and make it easier to obtain 
financing. PBank will play a pivotal role in serving commercial, SMEs, and the retail sectors. As 
the  primary  nationwide  bank  with  a  significant  presence  in  rural  areas,  PBank  will  be  able  to 
reach out to business enterprises and individuals in all areas of the country. To achieve these 
objectives,  the  Program  will  address  the  constraints  and  issues  identified  in  Section  III  B  on 
Issues and Opportunities. 
 
The  TA  loan  will  have  the  following  components:  (i)  capacity  building  and  skills 
78. 
development  for  PBank;  (ii)  strengthening  the  insurance  industry  through  capacity  building  of 
IBSL; (iii) support to create a national computerized movable property registry through capacity 
building  and  provision  of  computer  equipment;  (iv)  provision  of  banking  expertise  to  SEMA  to 
improve its ability to manage the banks in its portfolio; and (v) provision of legal and governance 
expertise  for  corporate  securities,  financial  markets,  commercial  and  banking  law,  and  policy 
reforms. 
 
Policy Framework and Actions 
 
79. 
 

The Program entails five policy outcomes in two focus areas: 

1.  Components and Outputs 

 
Focus Area 1: Development of Financial Markets  
Policy outcome 1.a: Increased Financial Products and Services Available to the Capital Market 
Policy outcome 1.b: Enhanced Corporate Governance in the Financial Market 
Policy outcome 1.c: Improved Regulations of the Insurance Industry 
 
Focus Area 2: Operational Improvement of State-Owned Commercial Banks 
Policy outcome 2.a: Improved Corporate Governance of State-owned Commercial Banks 
Policy outcome 2.b: Restructuring and Recapitalization of People's Bank 
 
Focus Area 1: Development of Financial Markets 

80. 
The  fundamental  objectives  of  developing  the  financial  markets  are  (i)  increased 
financial  products  and  services  available  to  the  capital  market,  (ii)  enhanced  corporate 
governance in the financial markets, and (iii) improved regulations of the insurance industry. 
 
Policy  Outcome 1.a: Increased Financial Products and Services Available to the Capital 

Market 

 
Financing  Through  Secured  Transactions.  The  Program  will  support  the  legal  and 
81. 
policy  reforms  to  modernize  Sri  Lanka's  secured24  transactions  system,  including  the 
establishment of a computerized national system of registration for securing movable property 
including  machinery  and/or  equipment,  which  will  make  it  easier  for  businesses  to  obtain 
financing by providing movable assets as collateral for loans. It will also support establishment 
or  appointment  of  an  agency  responsible  for  movable  property  registration.  Introduction  of  a 

                                                 
24 ADB  2001.  Technical  Assistance  to  Sri  Lanka  for  Enabling  SME  Growth  (TA  3822-SRI)  for  $1.2  million  included 
assistance for preparation of a Secured Transactions Bill. Because Parliament was dissolved in February 2004, the 
Bill was never brought to the Cabinet. It is presently being reviewed by the Government. 

 18 

 

Secured Transaction Bill and amendments to the Finance Companies Act into Parliament will be 
supported by the Program. 
 
82. 
Publicly  Traded  Securitized  Bonds.  The  Program  will  focus  on  introducing  publicly 
traded  securitized  bonds  in  the  capital  market.  A  Securitization  Bill  will  be  introduced  to 
Parliament,  whereby  special  purpose  vehicles  (SPVs)  may  be  established  as  separate  legal 
entities to pool real or intangible assets against which public securities may be issued. The SEC 
will  administer  and  provide  regulatory  supervision  of  SPVs.  Securitized  bonds  should  improve 
the financial sources available for the home mortgage market and other markets and industries. 
Publicly  traded  securitized  bonds  should  reduce  interest  rates  for  borrowers,  lower  the  credit 
risk for lenders and investors, increase liquidity in the bond market, and lengthen the yield curve 
for  bonds.  The  long-term  effects  will  be  to  reduce  interest  rates  and  strengthen  the  financial 
system. 
 
83. 
Improved Asset Risk Management. The Program will also encourage the development 
of new products and services to improve the performance and reduce the risks associated with 
asset  management  through  encouraging  (i)  the  CBSL  to  introduce  directives  for  interest  rate 
swaps; and (ii) the Government to permit public trading of derivatives and futures. The Program 
will also support the development of an equity clearing system cycle to improve the clearing of 
equity  securities  from  T+6  to  T+3.  The  SEC  will  initially  require  the  CSE  to  submit  a  plan  for 
implementing  the  new  clearing  system,  and  the  SEC  will  ensure  the  operationalization  of  the 
system within 3 years. 
 
84. 
Sovereign  Bonds.  The  Program  supports  the  creation  of  the  Public  Debt  Department 
within CBSL and the eventual creation of a Public Debt Office, which, through its establishment 
as  a  separate  authority  and  election  of  its  board  members,  will  become  independent  from 
political  or  economic  influence  from  the  CBSL  and  MOFP.  The  Public  Debt  Office  will  be 
responsible for the management, issuance, and modalities of all public debt and guarantees. An 
independent Public Debt Office issuing sovereign bonds through the price discovery method will 
improve  the  method  of  debt  issuance  and  lead  to  development  of  a  market  yield  curve.  Such 
reforms would (i) encourage corporate issuers to raise capital through the public bond market; 
(ii) improve debt market liquidity; and (iii) improve investor confidence, thereby attracting foreign 
investors. 
 
85. 
Harmonizing Taxes. The Program will encourage the tax laws to be harmonized so that 
the double taxation on money market mutual funds (withholding tax and tax on dividends) will be 
eliminated. Harmonizing the taxation rules on money market mutual funds through amendments 
to  the  Revenue  Act  and  the  Companies  Act  (if  needed)  would  improve  the  market  liquidity  of 
debt instruments. 
 
Policy Outcome 1.b: Enhanced Corporate Governance in the Financial Markets 

86. 
Enhanced  authority  to  SEC  and  CBSL  as  regulators.  The  Program  supports  the 
drafting of the Sri Lankan Corporate Governance Code. The SEC will become a more effective 
regulator by improving the reporting, regulations, and functional framework of the capital market 
by  issuing  a  directive  making  it  mandatory  for  listed  companies  to  follow  the  Sri  Lankan 
Corporate Governance Code. Additionally, CBSL shall be given the power to take action against 
fraudulent  financial  schemes  (e.g.  pyramid  schemes)  in  the  market  it  regulates.  To  reduce 
political  interference  in  capital  market  regulation,  the  SEC  commissioners  will  be  appointed  to 
reflect  diverse  public  and  private  interests  and  facilitate  an  independent  SEC.  Moreover,  an 
Anti-Money Laundering Bill will be drafted and submitted to Parliament for approval. 

  

 

19 

Policy Outcome 1.c: Improved Regulations of the Insurance Industry 
 
87. 
IBSL and the Insurance Act. The IBSL will be made operational by appointing a board 
of directors, a majority of whose members are from the private sector. Additional staff need to 
be hired to effectively implement, monitor, and supervise insurance companies. Also, to support 
increasing  the  availability  of  long-term  capital  and  the  number  of  institutional  investors  in  the 
bond  market,  amendments  will  be  made  to  the  Regulation  of  Insurance  Industry  Act  that  will 
permit insurance companies to invest in securitized bonds. 
 
Focus Area 2: Operational Improvement of State-Owned Commercial Banks 

Policy Outcome 2.a: Improved Corporate Governance of State-Owned Commercial Banks 

88. 
A bill will be introduced into Parliament, the SEMA Bill, to permit, among others things, 
BOC and PBank to make all business decisions without political interference or consideration, 
especially  pertaining  to  the  recruitment,  transfer,  and  promotion  of  employees.  The  amended 
BOC Act and PBank Acts will provide commercial and political independence to the boards and 
management  and  prevent  the  Government  from  intervening  in  the  day-to-day  affairs  of  these 
two banks, including their credit decisions and the interest rates they set on loans to SOEs. 
 
Policy Outcome 2.b: Restructuring and Recapitalization of People's Bank 

89. 
During  the  past  3  years,  PBank’s  management  has  significantly  improved  financial 
profitability. With the bank in a much stronger financial position, the Government has decided to 
recapitalize PBank (subject to certain prerequisites described below) for a maximum of SLRs8.5 
billion (approximately $82 million) in order to (i) improve PBank's financial viability and meet the 
CBSL’s  minimum  regulatory  CAR  requirements  to  operate  as  a  bank;  (ii)  strengthen  the 
country's financial system by having PBank become a strong, competitive, and profitable bank 
that  will  contribute  to  the  national  budget  and  become  a  source  of  capital  formation;  and  (iii) 
permit  PBank  to  continue  its  existing  business,  particularly  private  sector  and  SME  credit 
including  in  the  rural  areas  and  thereby  supporting  the  Government’s  development  and 
economic growth strategy. 
 
90. 
Prerequisites  for  the  Government  to  recapitalize  PBank  include  a  memorandum  of 
understanding  (MOU)  to  be  entered  into  between  (i)  the  Government  and  SEMA,  and  (ii)  the 
board  of  directors  and  management  of  PBank.  In  the  MOU,  management  and  the  board  of 
directors  would  agree  to  the  restructuring  plan  according  to the  agreed  schedule  and  meeting 
the  outlined  performance  targets.  After  appropriate  consultation  with  PBank  trade  unions  and 
the  existing  staff  management  briefing  and  feedback  system,  by  30  September  2005,  PBank 
must enter into a collective agreement (Collective Agreement) with the trade union representing 
more than 85% of the permanent employees of PBank. In the Collective Agreement, the parties 
agree  to  implement  the  restructuring  plan  and  meet  the  performance  targets.  All  appropriate 
labor rules and regulations will be adhered to. If the MOU and Collective Agreement are entered 
into  and  if  the  performance  targets  are  met,  the  Government  agrees  to  recapitalize  PBank  to 
meet  its  minimum  core  capital  ratio  requirements  in  accordance  with  the  phased-in 
recapitalization plan for a maximum amount of SLRs8.5 billion.  
 
91. 
An oversight committee appointed by the Government will closely assess the progress in 
resolving some of PBank's major weaknesses, particularly human resource management, and 
will  have  the  authority  to  make  corrections  to  the  restructuring  plan  as  needed.  As  part  of  the 
assessment,  an  independent  review  of  PBank  operations  will  be  performed  at  least  every  6 

 20 

 

months. Before the Government injects additional capital into PBank, an independent review of 
operations,  satisfactory  to  ADB,  will  be  conducted.  The  review  will  include  the  loan  books, 
collateral  security,  pension  funds,  the  value  of  investments  in  subsidiaries  and  associate 
companies,  and  information  technology  to  ascertain  sustainability  as  a  result  of  the  phased-in 
recapitalization. 
 
92. 
Due  to  PBank's  size,  customer  profile,  and  strength  of  its  labor  unions,  successful 
implementation of restructuring to resolve PBank's problems would entail close monitoring and 
oversight, and would need an estimated time  frame of three to five years. A discussion of the 
plans is presented below.  
 
93.

95. 
Restructuring  Plan.  Because  employees  are  promoted  based  on  tenure  rather  than 
skills  or  merit,  and  because  of  strict  labor  rules  regarding  involuntary  retrenchment,  PBank 
suffers  from  overstaffing,  ageing  employees  with  low  skill  levels,  and  a  poor  working  culture. 
PBank  also  has  an  unviable  branch  distribution  network  with  some  branches  not  generating 
sufficient  loan  volume  to  make  a  profit.  PBank  has  an  unacceptably  high  operational  cost 
structure with the cost/income ratio in excess of 70%. The increase in investment in technology 
could  further  increase  the  cost  ratio  in  2004.  More  than  one-third  of  the  staff  is  engaged  in 
administrative,  back-office,  and  non-core  functions.  The  age  profile  of  the  staff  is  unfavorable, 
with  more  than  60%  above  45  years.  More  than  2,400  employees  will  be  leaving  the  bank 
through retirement and/or natural attrition during the next several years. Under the restructuring 
plan, there is no VRS to retrench nonessential employees. In order to adjust for overall staffing, 
as  well  as  being  able  to  grow  and  have  the  proper  skills  for  the  bank  on  a  longer-term  basis, 
PBank has been and will continue to recruit one young graduate for every two retirees. Because 
young graduates require lower salaries and because the total number of jobs at PBank will have 
been reduced by 2008, net saving in payroll costs are estimated to be $15 million per year. 
 
96. 
The  restructuring  plan  includes  reorganizing  the  bank  into  three  divisions:  commercial, 
savings,  and  microfinance/pawning.  Unprofitable  branches  will  be  converted  to  savings  and 
pawning centers if the costs of having a full operational bank cannot be justified. If there were 
no banking facilities available in a town or  village, instead of closing down unviable branches, 
such branches would offer limited banking services. 
 
97. 
The  commercial  bank  loan  division  will  be  comprised  of  loans  to  industrial  clients, 
primarily  SMEs,  exporters,  and  middle-income  retail  clients.  Approximately  50  branches  will 
offer a full range of services and will be responsible for increasing the lending portfolio, which as 
a  result  of  its  cheap  funding  deposit  base  should  enhance  future  profitability.  Simple  low-risk 
retail loan products such as residential mortgage loans, vehicle loans, and educational loans will 
be offered, and appropriate risk grading and collection will be introduced. PBank plans to reduce 
its  high-risk  loan  exposure  to  SOEs,  from  the  present  level  of  24%  of  total  advances  net  of 
provisions  as  at  30  September  200425  to  20%  of  the  total  loan  portfolio  by  2006.  To  improve 
efficiency  and  profitability,  PBank  will  focus  on  middle-market  corporate  accounts  (enterprises 
that  could  absorb  a  loan  size  of  at  least  $50,000).  The  bank  is  also  adopting  aggressive  exit 
strategies for identified weak customer loans.  

                                                 
25  People’s  Bank’s  exposure  to  SOEs  was  26%  of  total  advances  net  of  provisions  as  at  31  December  2003.  The 
exposure increased to 27% in the first quarter of 2004 but subsequently declined, and in the third quarter of 2004, 
its present exposure is 24% of total advances, net of provisions. 

 22 

 

The savings bank division, which will have branches in urban as well as rural areas, will 
98. 
focus on savings mobilization. A $10 million information technology upgrade is anticipated to be 
completed  by  the  end  of  2004  or  early  2005,  after  which,  PBank  will  offer  straight-through 
remittance capabilities (i.e. deposits and/or withdrawals for Sri Lankans living abroad) and other 
services will be introduced to attract the middle-market expatriate customer, thereby improving 
the bank's foreign currency deposit base. 
 
99. 
PBank  is  a  market  leader  in  the  pawn  broking  business,  and  the  portfolio  has  grown 
consistently  every  year  with  an  exposure  of  SLRs23  billion  as  at  year  end  December  2003. 
PBank  will  extend  microlending 
to  all  viable  branches  nationwide.  To  make 
microfinance/pawning more profitable, the bank will use outsourcing wherever possible. 

 

100.  To improve performance of the recapitalized bank, a new management structure will be 
introduced, consisting of a five-person team that is directly accountable for the implementation 
of  the  restructuring  plan.  A  board-level  risk  management  committee  has  recently  been 
appointed to oversee measures to further reduce business risks. 
 
C. 

Important Features 

101.  Restructuring  and  Recapitalization  of  People’s  Bank.  The  Program  supports  the 
Government’s efforts to strengthen the banking system by further restructuring PBank, based on 
an  agreed  time  schedule  to  meet  certain  performance  and  profitability  targets.  PBank  will  be 
recapitalized in phases according to the recapitalization plan to meet the minimum core capital 
ratios to maintain its banking license. 
 
102.  Development  of  Financial  Markets.  The  Program  supports  the  development  of  the 
financial markets, one of the key constraints to economic growth, including SME development. 
The  Program  improves  the  efficiency  of  the  financial  markets,  increases  availability  of 
alternative  financial  sources  of  funding  to  the  private  sector,  and  improves  corporate 
governance. 
 
D. 

Financing Plan  

103.  The program loan will finance the cost of adjustment arising from the proposed reforms, 
whose total is estimated to be $90 million. The expected costs of the proposed reforms are: 
 

recapitalizing PBank ($82 million); 

drafting,  gazetting,  and  introducing  Acts  to  Parliament  under  the  policy  reform 
program  and  the  administrative  costs  for  SEMA  to  manage  PBank  ($3  million); 
and 

(i) 

(ii) 

(iii) 

establishing and operationalizing the Public Debt Office ($5 million). 

 
104.  The  proposed  Program  comprises  (i)  a  policy  loan,  and  (ii)  a  TA  loan,  totaling  $65 
million. 
 
105.  The  Policy  Loan.  The  Government  has  requested  a  loan  of  $60,000,000  will  be 
provided to Sri Lanka from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to help finance the Program. The 
loan  will  have  a  15-year  term,  including  a  grace  period  of  3  years,  an  interest  rate  to  be 
determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  London  interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based  lending 

  

 

23 

facility,  and  a  commitment  charge  for  the  undisbursed  balance  of  0.75%  per  annum.  (A  front-
end fee of 1% will be waived for loans approved before 30 June 2005). The loan will support a 
program of reforms and will be released in three equal tranches of $20 million each and such 
other terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan agreements. The Government has provided 
ADB with (i) reasons for its decision to borrow under ADB’s LIBOR-based lending facility on the 
basis  of  these  terms  and  conditions,  and  (ii)  an  undertaking  that  these  choices  were  its  own 
independent decision and not made in reliance on any communication or advice from ADB. 
 
106.  The Technical Assistance Loan. The TA loan of SDR3,318,000, will be provided to Sri 
Lanka  and  financed  from  ADB’s  Special  Funds  resources.  This  loan  will  have  a  term  of  32 
years, including a grace period of 8 years, and an interest rate of 1.0% per annum during the 
grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter. 
 
E. 

Implementation Arrangements 

Program Period 

1. 
 
Implementation is expected to last 3 years and is scheduled for completion in December 

107. 
2007. The program implementation schedule is included in Appendix 5. 
 

2. 

Procurement and Disbursement  

 
108.  The Policy Loan. In accordance with provisions of ADB’s Simplification of Disbursement 
Procedures and Related Requirements for Program Loans, the proceeds of the policy loan will 
be disbursed to the Government as the Borrower. The proceeds of the policy loan will be utilized 
to finance the full foreign exchange costs (excluding local duties and taxes) of imports produced 
in and procured from ADB’s member countries, other than those specified in the list of ineligible 
items  (Appendix  6)  and  imports  financed  by  other  bilateral  and  multilateral  sources.  All 
procurement  will  be  through  normal  commercial  practices  in  the  case  of  procurement  by  the 
private sector, or prescribed procedures acceptable to ADB in the case of procurement by the 
public sector, having due regard to the principles of economy and efficiency. The Government 
will certify that (i) the value of the country’s eligible imports is equal to or exceeds the amounts 
of ADB’s projected disbursements under the policy loan in a given period; and (ii) the policy loan 
proceeds will be accurately utilized in a manner satisfactory to ADB. The policy loan proceeds 
will be disbursed on the basis of the certification provided by the Government, which confirms 
that the above requirements for the policy loan have been met. ADB will have the right to audit 
the  use  of  the  loan  proceeds  and  to  verify  the  accuracy  of  the  Government’s  certification.  All 
procurement  under  the  loan  will  be  undertaken  through  normal  commercial  practices  for  the 
private sector or the Government’s prescribed procurement procedures acceptable to ADB, with 
due consideration to economy and efficiency. The list of ineligible items is in Appendix 6. 
 
109.  The  TA  loan.  Procurement  of  goods  and  services  will  be  subject  to  the  provisions  of 
ADB’s  Guidelines  for  Procurement.  Office  equipment  and  computers  will  be  procured  through 
international  competitive  bidding  for  packages  exceeding  $500,000  equivalent,  and  through 
international  shopping  procedures  for  packages  between  $100,000  and  $500,000  equivalent. 
For packages below $100,000 equivalent, direct purchase may be used. 
 
110.  Consultants under the TA loan will be recruited as individuals in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  and  other  arrangements  satisfactory  to  ADB  for  the 
engagement of domestic consultants.  
 

 24 

 

3. 

Counterpart Funds 

111.  Counterpart  funds  will  be  used  to  meet  program  expenditures  and  associated  costs  of 
reform. 
 

4. 

Monitoring and Tranching  

112.  The  proceeds  of the  policy  loan  will  be  available  for  withdrawal in three tranches upon 
satisfactory compliance with agreed policy actions as outlined in the Policy Matrix in Appendix 3. 
First  tranche  will  be  released  upon  loan  effectiveness;  the  subsequent  two  tranches  will  be 
released  during  the  Program  period  of  3  years,  tentatively  envisaged  18  and  36  months  after 
loan  effectiveness,  respectively.  ADB  and  the  Government  would  review  the  progress  of 
implementation  of  specified  policy  actions  set  out  in  the  policy  matrix  through  periodic  review 
missions. A comprehensive mid-term review will be undertaken before the scheduled release of 
the second tranche.  
 

5. 

Program Management 

113.  MOFP  will  be  the  Executing  Agency  for  the  Program  and  the  CBSL,  IBSL,  PBank,  the 
Land  Commissioner’s  Department,  and  SEMA  will  be  the  Implementing  Agencies.  A  steering 
committee  will  be  formed  chaired by  the  Secretary,  MOFP,  to  coordinate  policy  decisions  that 
may  need  to  be  taken  to  pursue  reforms  under  the  Program.  The  committee,  which  will  meet 
regularly  and  as  needed,  is  made  up  of  key  officials  from  concerned  ministries  and  agencies. 
The  steering  committee  may  also  call  upon  affected  sectors  for  consultations  on  important 
issues  that  will  have  a  bearing  on  the  Program,  such  as  the  labor  unions,  employers’ 
federations, nongovernment organizations, academics, PBank, and the CSE.  
 

6. 

Accounting, Auditing, and Reporting  

114.  An  audit  of  the  use  of  the  loan  proceeds  of  the  policy  loan  will  be  undertaken  if 
requested  by  ADB.  ADB  retains  the  right  to  audit  any  account  and  verify  the  validity  of  the 
certification issued by the Government for each withdrawal application. Prior to withdrawal, the 
Government  will  open  a  deposit  account  at  CBSL  to  receive  loan  proceeds.  Accounting, 
auditing, and reporting procedures for the TA loan are contained in Appendix 7. 
 

7. 

Program Performance Monitoring and Evaluation  

115.  MOFP will establish a program performance management system (PPMS) as agreed on 
with ADB, and cause it to be operated throughout Program implementation. Under the PPMS, 
MOFP  will  periodically  review  the  Program  for  evaluation  of  the  scope,  implementation 
arrangements, benefit monitoring, progress, and achievements. Quarterly PPMS reports in line 
with  ADB's  PPMS  Guidelines  will  be  submitted  to  the  coordination  committee  of  the  Program, 
made available to ADB and published. Not later than 3 months after program completion, MOFP 
will provide ADB with a report, including an assessment of overall program performance.

(v) training for middle and upper management.

Capacity Building and Skills Development for PBank

Implementation Arrangements 

VI. 

PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 

 
A. 

Program Benefits  

125.  There  is  broad  consensus  that  the  future  development  of  Sri  Lanka  hinges  on  a 
permanent peaceful resolution of the civil conflict, and maintaining high economic growth. Only 
through  higher  and  sustained  growth  can  the  country  create  jobs,  raise  standards  of  living, 
maintain high levels of human development, and reduce poverty. 
 
126.  The Program, which supports private sector development, will assist the Government in 
meeting its development objectives. It will help facilitate access by the private sector, including 
SMEs,  to  domestic  sources  of  financing  and  capital.  It  will  also  support  the  development  of  a 
sound,  more  competitive,  banking  system  through  the  restructuring  and  recapitalization  of 
PBank.  Mortgage  financing  will  become  more  readily  available  which  will  improve  the  quality 
and cost of housing throughout the country. 
 
127.  PBank  will  provide  better  financial  products  and  services  that  specifically  address  the 
SME market, especially in rural areas. An expanding SME sector will stimulate demand for labor 
and lead to the shifting of workers from agriculture and non-wage employment to jobs of higher 
productivity and higher wages in industry and services. This growth in overall employment and 
the intersectoral shifting of workers will reduce poverty. Income and employment generation will 

  

 

27 

increase. New jobs will reduce disguised unemployment and underemployment among the less 
educated  low-income  people,  thus  helping  reduce  the  extent  of  poverty.  Since  women 
traditionally  account  for  nearly  half  of  workers  in  the  SME  sector,  the  Program  should  have  a 
favorable impact on the employment and income of women. 
  
Environmental and Social Impacts  

128.  The  Program  is  classified  under  category  C  of  ADB’s  environmental  classification 
system.  There  is  no  investment  project  included  in  the  Program  and  no  direct  environmental 
impact is expected. The Program is not expected to generate adverse social impacts requiring 
corresponding  mitigating  measures.  The  matrix  of  potential  environment  impact  on  policy 
actions is in Appendix 8. The summary poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 9. 
 
Risks 

129. 
 Political Risk. The present cease-fire is in effect after a 20-year civil war, and although 
the  Government  has  a  clear  intent to  seek  a  peaceful  resolution  of  the  conflict,  no  permanent 
solution has yet been reached. Delay of the progress in the peace process could potentially (i) 
weaken  private  sector  development  and  SME  growth;  (ii)  hinder  the  development  of  financial 
markets,  including  attracting  the  needed  investment  capital  to  rebuild  and/or  modernize  the 
infrastructure of the country; and (iii) undermine the political will to introduce and implement the 
necessary policy reforms.  
 
130. 
Implementation  Risk.  Implementation  of  reform  may  be  delayed  because  of  a  lack  of 
capacity and/or skills. The Government has established theme cluster groups, focusing on the 
policies and their implementation, and capacity building through the TA loan is an integral part 
of the Program. 
 
131.  The  law  and  policy  reform  components  of  the  Program  involve  various  bills,  and/or 
amendments to existing acts pertaining to financial and commercial reforms to be approved by 
the  Cabinet  and  introduced  in  Parliament.  This  includes  the  SEMA  Act  which  is  a  key 
component of the Program. However, there are political risks that such bills and/or amendments 
may  not  be  enacted  by  Parliament  despite  the  Government’s  strong  commitment,  and  if 
enacted, may not be implemented. 
 
132.  The risk in recapitalizing PBank is whether management will be successful in meeting or 
exceeding  the  performance  targets  in  the  restructuring  plan,  including  the  repayment  of  the 
capital  injected  by  the  Government.  The  bank  must  also  generate  sufficient  income  to  meet 
capital adequacy requirements in line with the projected growth in assets.  
 
133.  Restructuring of PBank has substantial labor and human relations issues. Labor unions 
in  Sri  Lanka  are  active  and  their  acceptance  of  the  restructuring  plan  will  be  key  to  effective 
implementation under the Program. PBank is required to enter into an agreement with the union 
representing  85%  of  the  employees  by  30  September  2005.  There  is  a  risk  that  this  may  not 
occur. 
 
134.  Macroeconomic  Risk.  Despite  generally  sound  economic  developments,  the  fiscal 
deficit has begun to widen in 2004 reflecting inter alia some weakening in revenue performance, 
increased  government  spending,  a  prolonged  drought  and  petroleum  price  subsidies,  which 
have  been  exacerbated  due  to  oil  prices  remaining  at  an  all-time  high.  The  new  Government 
has yet to start negotiation on a new Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility (PRGF) as some 

 28 

 

performance  criteria  and  structural  conditions  under  the  now  suspended  PRGF  were  not  met. 
However,  following  political  developments,  including  the  dissolution  of  Parliament  in  February 
2004  and  the  general  election  of  April  2004,  the  new  Government  is  firming  up  key 
macroeconomic  policies  and  is  in  discussions  with  IMF  on  the  resumption  of  PRGF.  Looking 
forward,  the  PRGF  is  not  likely  to  be  renewed  before  early  2005  following  the  finalization  of 
actual results from the 2004 budget and supporting economic policy framework action plans.

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE LOAN FOR SUPPORTING THE PRIVATE SECTOR AND 
FINANCIAL MARKETS DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM 

Objectives and Scope  

Background and Rationale  

 
A. 
 
1. 
The Financial Markets Program for Private Sector Development (the Program) formerly 
Private  Sector  Development  Program  (PSDP)  subprogram  II  is  the  second  subprogram  of  the 
cluster  loan  approved  by  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  in  December  2000  and  is 
designed  to  support  the  creation  of  an  enabling  environment  for  private  sector  development. 
The  Program  and  actions  are  intended  to  complement  the  results  achieved  by  the  PSDP 
subprogram I, particularly in the areas of (i) developing financial markets and the private sector's 
access  to  finance,  and  (ii)  strengthening  the  banking  system  so  it  becomes  more  competitive 
and  continue  providing  banking  services  to  the  rural  areas  by:  (a)  restructuring  the  second 
largest bank in the country, the state-owned bank, People’s Bank (PBank); (b) simultaneously 
implementing  performance  targets  according  to  the  agreed  schedule  to  improve  its  efficiency 
and profitability; and (c) recapitalizing the bank in accordance with the phased-in recapitalization 
plan. The Program will be implemented from 2005 to 2007. It consists of two loans: (a) a policy 
loan, amounting to $60 million from ADB’s ordinary capital resources (OCR) and (b) a technical 
assistance (TA) loan, amounting to $5 million equivalent from ADB’s Special Funds resources. 
 
B.  
 
2. 
The TA Loan’s objective is to provide technical assistance to support the Program. The 
principal objective of the Program is to facilitate private sector development by strengthening the 
financial  markets,  including  the  restructuring  and  phased  recapitalization  of  People’s  Bank 
(PBank).  The  scope  includes  (i)  development  of  financial  markets  through  (a)  increasing  the 
availability  of  financial  products  and  services  to  the  financial  market;  (b)  enhancing  corporate 
governance  in  the  financial  market;  (c)  improving  insurance  industry  regulation;  and  (ii) 
strengthening the banking system through (a) improving corporate governance of state-owned 
commercial banks, and (b) restructuring the state-owned PBank. 
 
3. 
In this context, the Program will support the development of financial markets, one of the 
key constraints of economic growth for the private sector and SMEs. PBank will play a pivotal 
role in servicing SMEs. As a nationwide bank, it will be able to reach out to businesses as well 
as to the retail population in all areas of the country.  
 
The  TA  loan  will:  (i)  provide  capacity  building  and  skills  development  for  PBank;  (ii) 
4. 
strengthen the insurance industry through capacity building at the Insurance Board of Sri Lanka 
(IBSL);  (iii)  support  creation  of  a  national  computerized  registry  for  codifying,  operating  and 
maintaining  movable  property  to  be  used  for  secured  transaction  financing;  (iv)  strengthen 
banking  expertise  at  the  Strategic  Enterprise  Management  Agency  (SEMA)  to  improve  its 
management  of  the  four  banks  in  its  portfolio; and  (v)  develop  the  necessary  domestic  and/or 
international skills to draft appropriate regulations and legislation for the Program.

SUMMARY POVERTY REDUCTION AND SOCIAL STRATEGY 

 
A. 

Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis 

Is the sector identified as a national 
priority in country poverty analysis?   

 

 

 

 

  Yes 

    No 

 

Is the sector identified as a national 
priority in country poverty partnership 
agreement?   

 
 Yes 
 
  No 

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Sri Lanka: 
The Financial Markets Program for Private Sector Development is designed to reinforce the achievement of the PSDP 
subprogram I by providing further support to (i) increase private sector access to finance through development of the 
financial markets; and (ii) restructure and recapitalize People’s Bank, a national bank with a strong presence in rural 
and  poor  areas  of  the  country.  It  is  expected  that  the  outcomes  of  effective  financial  services  and  products  and 
prudent corporate governance in the capital market, and market-friendly investment environment will reduce the cost 
of financing, provide additional financial alternatives to small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), increase private 
sector  investment,  employment  generation,  and  provide  knowledge  and  expertise  in  all  sectors.  Furthermore,  by 
restructuring  People’s  Bank  and  reducing  its  economic  burden  on  the  national  budget,  positive  implications  on 
economic productivity, employment generation, fiscal management, and GDP growth will result in the long run.   
As the Program focuses on developing financial markets and strengthening the banking and insurance industries, the 
private  sector-led  pro-poor  economic  growth  would  provide  better  access  to  credit,  savings  and  insurance  products, 
thereby, reducing the vulnerability of the poor.     

 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                          Targeting Classification: General Intervention 
 

What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
The Program is indirectly pro-poor in supporting the three components of ADB’s poverty reduction strategy: pro-poor 
sustainable economic growth, good governance, and social development.  Pro-poor sustainable economic growth is to 
be achieved through the Program’s focus on measures to improve the financial soundness of the banking system and 
capital market, strengthen investor confidence and increase private sector investment. This, in turn, will attract more 
investment  capital  for  much  needed  infrastructure  in  the  rural  area,  provide  employment,  and  raise  income  for  the 
poor. To support good governance, the Program focuses on strengthening the regulating authorities and regulations in 
the  capital  markets  and  banking  system.  It  will  therefore  improve  transparency  through  required  information 
disclosure,  effectiveness  of  regulation  and  enforcement,  and,  ultimately,  sustainable  economic  development.  The 
Program  also  supports  reforms  for  business  regulation,  strengthening  property  rights,  and  removing  obstacles  for 
doing  business.  Through  such  reforms,  establishment  of  new  businesses  will  be  encouraged,  jobs  will  be  created, 
businesses  will  be  encouraged  to  move  into  the  formal  economy,  and  more  investment  capital  will  be  available  to 
stimulate economic growth. In addition, the Program supports better fiscal management and eventual reduction in the 
debt  burden  of  the  country  by  restructuring  and  recapitalizing  People’s  Bank.  To  support  the  poverty  reduction 
strategy’s  third  pillar  of  social  development,  the  Program  supports  reforms  in  social  protection  programs  such  as 
reductions in the number of employees through natural attrition or retirement, which will provide long-term additional 
optional  protection  to  the  vulnerable  poor.  Additionally,  through  the  development  of  new  financial  products,  it  will  be 
easier  to  obtain  less  expensive  mortgage  financing,  which  will  result  in  more  people  being  able  to  afford  proper 
housing and will have a sustainable effect on overall poverty reduction. 

 
C.  Participation Process 

  Yes

Is there a stakeholder analysis? 
Periodic stakeholder consultation has been conducted throughout the Program formulation, but did not require specific 
stakeholder analysis, as direct impacts on specific stakeholder groups are limited. 
 
Is there a participation strategy? 
During preparation of the Program, the Mission consulted with all relevant stakeholders to structure representative and 
broad strategy for participation by the general population for the private sector, including SMEs, and financial market 
development. In addition, People's Bank, with a strong presence in rural areas, will be recapitalized and restructured 
to better serve the rural poor.

 D.  Gender Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
By increasing the availability of SME financing (i.e., through strengthening of People’s Bank), particularly in the rural 
area,  women,  who primarily  work for no  wages as household help,  would be given the opportunity to establish their 
own business.
